title: Doing Business 2020: Putting India’s performance in perspective
text:
India’s performance in the World Bank’s annual Doing Business ranking continues to improve.

In Doing Business 2020, India’s rank was 63rd, up 14 places. To go back farther, it was 130th in 2016. More impressive is the fact that for the third consecutive time India was among the world’s top 10 performers.

Two of India’s neighbours, Pakistan and China, were also among the top 10 improvers.

Doing Business ranking is based on 12 metrics and covers two cities in India, Mumbai and Delhi. According to World Bank, it measures aspects of business regulation affecting small business firms located in the largest business city.

As India’s population exceeds 100 million, the data is collected from two cities.

The report is balanced in the sense that it highlights some areas it does not measure such as corruption.

How is the measurement undertaken?

According to World Bank, it is undertaken primarily on the basis of the statute books.

“Approximately, two-thirds of the data embedded in the Doing Business indicators are based on a reading of the law,” says the Doing Business 2020 report.

How does one put the report and India’s performance in perspective?

India’s performance is impressive and Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government deserves credit for making a persistent attempt to remove obstacles to ease of doing business. However, it is not enough to make big difference to the investment climate.

To illustrate, the rankings of Vietnam and Bangladesh provide food for thought. These countries are held up as good examples in an independent World Bank report on global value chains. Both countries are among top performers in exports in their areas of strength.

In the case of Vietnam it is electronics. Bangladesh has now become a top performer in apparel and textile exports.

In Doing Business 2020 rankings, Vietnam stands at 70 and Bangladesh at 168.

Pakistan is ranked 108th even though it hasn’t achieved anything on the scale Bangladesh has in the recent past.

The takeaway is that impressive as India’s performance is, there is a lot more to enhancing competitiveness of domestic firms and making them resilient in a competitive world. The government shouldn’t lose focus on that.
